Description: Fragment of a clay seal-impression showing a concave rear with wood impression, probably originating from a peg or knob. In the break two impressions of a turned string with a width of 0.30 cm. The front shows one impression of a scarab-like seal, with the sides of the sealing bending downwards, many finger impressions around it. The seal impression is cut very sharply and shows a circumferential line that thickens at the top. The upper part of the seal is preserved, visible is a bound captive on the left side, kneeling, facing towards the left, with his hands bound together at his back. Behind him on the right a seated lion with its front paws on the shoulder of the captive. Behind the back of the lion a small upright cobra, facing to the right. The remaining part is broken off but she same motif can be found on EA86927, EA86928, EA86930, EA86932, EA86933 and EA86934.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amara West (Nubia), E14.7 temple magazine
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
